message.content: hi claude. i'd like to create a gh issue which describes going over every file in this repository to start

content.text: I'll help you create a GitHub issue to track the review of all files in your dotfiles repository. Let me first check the current state of the repository and then create a comprehensive issue.

input.command:
gh issue create --title "Repository-wide file review and cleanup" --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Overview
Complete review of all 109 files in the dotfiles repository to ensure proper organization, remove unnecessary files, and validate configurations.

## Objectives
- [ ] Review each file for necessity and current usage
- [ ] Remove cache files, temporary files, and build artifacts
- [ ] Ensure no sensitive information is tracked
- [ ] Validate all configurations are working
- [ ] Update `.gitignore` as needed
- [ ] Document any special handling requirements

## File Categories to Review

### Core Shell Configuration
- [ ] `zshrc` - Main Zsh configuration
- [ ] `zshrc2` - Alternative/backup config
- [ ] `zshenv` - Environment variables
- [ ] `nvmrc` - Node version management

### Git & Version Control
- [ ] `gitconfig` - Git configuration
- [ ] `.gitignore` - Ignore patterns
- [ ] `.github/` directory - GitHub Actions and templates

### Tool Configurations
- [ ] `aider.conf.yml` - Aider AI assistant config
- [ ] `rcrc` - rcm configuration for dotfile management
- [ ] `alacritty/` - Terminal emulator config
- [ ] `fastfetch/` - System info tool config
- [ ] `i3/` - Window manager config
- [ ] `kitty/` - Terminal emulator config
- [ ] `nvim/` - Neovim editor config
- [ ] `zed/` - Zed editor config

### AI & CLI Tools
- [ ] `config/aichat/` - AI chat configurations
- [ ] `skogai/` - SkogAI tool configurations
- [ ] `basic-memory/` - Memory system config
- [ ] `amy/` - Amy assistant scripts
- [ ] `dot/` - Dot tool scripts

### Completions & Scripts
- [ ] `zsh-completions/` - Shell completions
- [ ] `scripts/` - Utility scripts
- [ ] `bin/` - Executable scripts

### Documentation
- [ ] `README.md` - Main documentation
- [ ] `CLAUDE.md` - Claude Code instructions
- [ ] `TODO.md` - Task tracking
- [ ] `ZNT.md` - Zsh Navigation Tools docs

## Review Checklist for Each File

For each file/directory:
1. **Purpose**: Is this file actively used?
2. **Location**: Is it in the right place?
3. **Privacy**: Does it contain sensitive data?
4. **Version Control**: Should it be tracked in git?
5. **Dependencies**: Are there missing dependencies?
6. **Documentation**: Is usage documented?

## Special Considerations

### Files to Remove
- Cache files (`.cache`, `__pycache__`, etc.)
- Session/history files that shouldn't be tracked
- Temporary or generated files
- Outdated/unused configurations

### Files Needing Special Handling
- SSH keys (should be copied, not symlinked per `rcrc`)
- API keys and tokens (managed via skogcli)
- Machine-specific configurations

## Progress Tracking

- [ ] Initial file inventory completed
- [ ] Categories defined and organized
- [ ] First pass review (remove obvious unnecessary files)
- [ ] Second pass review (validate configurations)
- [ ] Update `.gitignore` with discovered patterns
- [ ] Final cleanup and commit

## Notes
- Using rcm for dotfile management (`rcup`, `lsrc` commands)
- Environment variables managed via skogcli
- Following XDG Base Directory specification where applicable

---
Created: $(date +%Y-%m-%d)
Total files to review: 109
EOF
)"
input.description: Create comprehensive GitHub issue for repository review

# SkogAI CLI

[![CI](https://github.com/yourusername/skogai/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/yourusername/skogai/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
[![Documentation Status](https://github.com/yourusername/skogai/actions/workflows/docs.yml/badge.svg)](https://yourusername.github.io/skogai/)
[![codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/yourusername/skogai/branch/main/graph/badge.svg)](https://codecov.io/gh/yourusername/skogai)
[![PyPI version](https://badge.fury.io/py/skogai.svg)](https://badge.fury.io/py/skogai)

A modular and extensible CLI tool for managing AI-powered workflows and configurations.

## Features

- **Settings Management**: Efficient handling of configuration with in-memory caching
- **Location Navigation**: Quick navigation to project locations with tmux integration
- **Script Operations**: Run and manage scripts with parameter support
- **Agent Management**: Handle AI agents and their configurations
- **Extensible Design**: Easy to add new commands and functionality

## Installation

```bash
pip install skogai
```

## Quick Start

1. Initialize settings:

```bash
skogai settings ls
```

2. Navigate to a location:

```bash
skogai goto location my-project
```

3. Run a script:

```bash
skogai script run my-script --param value
```

## Documentation

For detailed documentation and API reference, visit [our documentation site](https://yourusername.github.io/skogai/).

### Development

### Prerequisites

content.content: # SKOGAI.md "If it doesn't fit anywhere else, it goes here" "(Or if Skogix doesn't want to talk.)" Mostly used by appending a row and going through it when time allows. ### temporary-dotskogai/commands är output från "typer skogai util docs" ~/cli/temporary-wotskogai goes in .skogai later TODO: temporary-dotskogai/development-phases TODO: development-phases .md .dump is a dump folder, remove later -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Cache Settings in Memory -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Currently, every call to load_settings and save_settings reads/writes the categories from/to disk. This can become expensive if the CLI is used frequently. A simple way to optimize is to cache the settings in memory. o • Only read from disk when the category is first requested (lazy loading). • Update the cache when settings are changed. • Write to disk only when settings are explicitly saved. Example (manager.py): -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- # manager.py (Optimized) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- import json from .defaults import DEFAULTS from pathlib import Path CONFIG_DIR = Path("/home/skogix/.config/skogai") # In-memory cache to avoid repeated file reads _settings_cache = {} def ensure_config_file(category): """Ensure the config file exists, otherwise create it with defaults.""" file_path = CONFIG_DIR / f"{category}.json" CONFIG_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True) if not file_path.exists(): default_data = DEFAULTS.get(category, {}) with open(file_path, "w") as f: # Use minimal indentation for faster writes json.dump(default_data, f) return file_path def load_settings(category): """Load settings from a JSON file, with an in-memory cache for reuse.""" # If already in cache, return immediately if category in _settings_cache: return _settings_cache[category] file_path = ensure_config_file(category) # If file is empty or just created, populate with DEFAULTS if file_path.stat().st_size == 0: data = DEFAULTS.get(category, {}) _settings_cache[category] = data return data # Otherwise, load from disk and cache the result with open(file_path, "r") as f: data = json.load(f) _settings_cache[category] = data return data def save_settings(category: str, data): """Saves settings to a JSON file and updates the in-memory cache.""" file_path = ensure_config_file(category) # Update the cache so subsequent calls don’t have to read from disk _settings_cache[category] = data # Write to disk with open(file_path, "w") as f: # Consider omitting indent=4 for better performance json.dump(data, f, indent=4) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2. Remove Eager Creation of All Config Files -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In the original code, every default config file is created at import time: for category in DEFAULTS.keys(): ensure_config_file(category) If you do not strictly need these files created ahead of time, consider removing this loop (or making it optional). That way, config files are only created when actually needed. This reduces file I/O at startup. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 3. Consider Lightweight JSON Libraries or Less Verbose Dumps --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mostly used by appending a row and going through it when time allows. ### temporary-dotskogai/commands är output från "typer skogai util docs" ~/cli/temporary-wotskogai goes in .skogai later TODO: temporary-dotskogai/development-phases TODO: development-phases .md .dump is a dump folder, remove later -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Cache Settings in Memory -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Currently, every call to load_settings and save_settings reads/writes the categories from/to disk. This can become expensive if the CLI is used frequently. A simple way to optimize is to cache the settings in memory. o • Only read from disk when the category is first requested (lazy loading). • Update the cache when settings are changed. • Write to disk only when settings are explicitly saved. Example (manager.py): -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- # manager.py (Optimized) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- import json from .defaults import DEFAULTS from pathlib import Path CONFIG_DIR = Path("/home/skogix/.config/skogai") # In-memory cache to avoid repeated file reads _settings_cache = {} def ensure_config_file(category): """Ensure the config file exists, otherwise create it with defaults.""" file_path = CONFIG_DIR / f"{category}.json" CONFIG_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True) if not file_path.exists(): default_data = DEFAULTS.get(category, {}) with open(file_path, "w") as f: # Use minimal indentation for faster writes json.dump(default_data, f) return file_path def load_settings(category): """Load settings from a JSON file, with an in-memory cache for reuse.""" # If already in cache, return immediately if category in _settings_cache: return _settings_cache[category] file_path = ensure_config_file(category) # If file is empty or just created, populate with DEFAULTS if file_path.stat().st_size == 0: data = DEFAULTS.get(category, {}) _settings_cache[category] = data return data # Otherwise, load from disk and cache the result with open(file_path, "r") as f: data = json.load(f) _settings_cache[category] = data return data def save_settings(category: str, data): """Saves settings to a JSON file and updates the in-memory cache.""" file_path = ensure_config_file(category) # Update the cache so subsequent calls don’t have to read from disk _settings_cache[category] = data # Write to disk with open(file_path, "w") as f: # Consider omitting indent=4 for better performance json.dump(data, f, indent=4) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2. Remove Eager Creation of All Config Files -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In the original code, every default config file is created at import time: for category in DEFAULTS.keys(): ensure_config_file(category) If you do not strictly need these files created ahead of time, consider removing this loop (or making it optional). That way, config files are only created when actually needed. This reduces file I/O at startup. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 3. Consider Lightweight JSON Libraries or Less Verbose Dumps --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

content.content:
## Workflow

### Development Workflow

Our development workflow involves the following steps:

1. **Request Information**: I ask for a folder of information.
2. **Update Documentation**: Update the relevant documentation files with the new information.
3. **Request Next Folder**: Repeat the process by asking for the next folder.

The reason we do it in two steps is that we can clear your context / memory in between and then start fresh with this workflow, plan, and todo.

#### Plan

For detailed planning and roadmap information, refer to the [PLAN.md](PLAN.md) file.

#### To-Do

For current tasks and ongoing development, refer to the [TODO.md](TODO.md) file.

input.content:
# Old-Merge Branch Recovery Analysis

## Overview
The `origin/old-merge` branch contains 156 file differences from the current master branch. After analysis, here are the potentially valuable items worth recovering:

## High Priority Items to Consider

### 1. SkogAI Documentation & Workflow (`.skogai/` directory)
**Value**: Comprehensive documentation and workflow guides that were lost
- `.skogai/README.md` - SkogAI CLI documentation with badges and setup instructions
- `.skogai/SKOGAI.md` - Technical notes and optimization strategies (cache settings, memory optimization)
- `.skogai/WORKFLOW.md` - Development workflow documentation
- `.skogai/PLAN.md` - Project planning and roadmap
- `.skogai/TODO.md` - Historical task tracking
- `.skogai/automation.md` - Automation strategies

### 2. Development Phases Documentation
**Value**: Structured development methodology
- `.skogai/development-phases/0-brainstorm.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/1-planning.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/2-testing.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/3-implementation.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/readme.md`

### 3. Aider Configuration
**Value**: AI assistant configurations and rules
- `.skogai/aider/aider.commands` - Custom aider commands
- `.skogai/aider/aider.conventions.md` - Coding conventions for AI
- `.skogai/aider/aider.rules.yml` - Aider behavior rules
- `.skogai/aider/aider.watchlist` - Files to watch
- `.skogai/aider/aider.env` - Environment configuration

### 4. Cursor Rules
**Value**: IDE-specific configuration
- `.cursor/rules/documentation-first.mdc` - Documentation-first development rules

### 5. Shell Configurations
**Value**: Alternative shell setups
- `bash_profile` - Bash profile configuration
- `bash_logout` - Bash logout scripts
- `bashrc` - Bash configuration (currently missing in master)
- `p10k.zsh` - PowerLevel10k theme configuration

### 6. VSCode Workspace
**Value**: Project workspace settings
- `.skogai/.dotfiles.code-workspace` - VSCode workspace configuration

## Medium Priority Items

### 1. Documentation Files
- `.skogai/AIDER-INSTRUCTIONS.md` - Instructions for using Aider
- `.skogai/documentation-first.md` - Documentation methodology
- `.docs/byobu.md` - Byobu/tmux documentation (moved from config/)

### 2. Configuration Differences
- Various config file reorganizations and movements
- Some configs have been restructured differently in old-merge

## Low Priority / Already Handled

### 1. Deleted Scripts
The i3 scripts that were deleted from master don't exist in old-merge either, so no recovery needed there.

### 2. GitHub Workflows
The GitHub Actions workflows (`.github/`) were removed in old-merge, which might have been intentional.

## Recommended Recovery Actions

1. **Recover SkogAI Documentation**: The entire `.skogai/` directory contains valuable documentation and workflow guides that should be reviewed and potentially merged back.

2. **Evaluate Aider Configuration**: The aider setup in `.skogai/aider/` might have useful configurations worth preserving.

3. **Consider Shell Configs**: If you're missing bash configurations, the `bashrc`, `bash_profile`, and `bash_logout` files might be worth recovering.

4. **PowerLevel10k Theme**: If you use or want to use P10k, the `p10k.zsh` configuration could be valuable.

## Commands to Cherry-Pick Specific Items

```bash
# To view a specific file from old-merge:
git show origin/old-merge:path/to/file

# To recover a specific file:
git checkout origin/old-merge -- path/to/file

# To selectively merge content:
git checkout -p origin/old-merge -- path/to/file
```

## Next Steps

1. Review the `.skogai/` directory contents in detail
2. Decide which documentation to recover
3. Check if any aider configurations are still relevant
4. Determine if bash configurations are needed
5. Consider creating a feature branch to test recovered items before merging to master

toolUseResult.content:
# Old-Merge Branch Recovery Analysis

## Overview
The `origin/old-merge` branch contains 156 file differences from the current master branch. After analysis, here are the potentially valuable items worth recovering:

## High Priority Items to Consider

### 1. SkogAI Documentation & Workflow (`.skogai/` directory)
**Value**: Comprehensive documentation and workflow guides that were lost
- `.skogai/README.md` - SkogAI CLI documentation with badges and setup instructions
- `.skogai/SKOGAI.md` - Technical notes and optimization strategies (cache settings, memory optimization)
- `.skogai/WORKFLOW.md` - Development workflow documentation
- `.skogai/PLAN.md` - Project planning and roadmap
- `.skogai/TODO.md` - Historical task tracking
- `.skogai/automation.md` - Automation strategies

### 2. Development Phases Documentation
**Value**: Structured development methodology
- `.skogai/development-phases/0-brainstorm.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/1-planning.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/2-testing.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/3-implementation.md`
- `.skogai/development-phases/readme.md`

### 3. Aider Configuration
**Value**: AI assistant configurations and rules
- `.skogai/aider/aider.commands` - Custom aider commands
- `.skogai/aider/aider.conventions.md` - Coding conventions for AI
- `.skogai/aider/aider.rules.yml` - Aider behavior rules
- `.skogai/aider/aider.watchlist` - Files to watch
- `.skogai/aider/aider.env` - Environment configuration

### 4. Cursor Rules
**Value**: IDE-specific configuration
- `.cursor/rules/documentation-first.mdc` - Documentation-first development rules

### 5. Shell Configurations
**Value**: Alternative shell setups
- `bash_profile` - Bash profile configuration
- `bash_logout` - Bash logout scripts
- `bashrc` - Bash configuration (currently missing in master)
- `p10k.zsh` - PowerLevel10k theme configuration

### 6. VSCode Workspace
**Value**: Project workspace settings
- `.skogai/.dotfiles.code-workspace` - VSCode workspace configuration

## Medium Priority Items

### 1. Documentation Files
- `.skogai/AIDER-INSTRUCTIONS.md` - Instructions for using Aider
- `.skogai/documentation-first.md` - Documentation methodology
- `.docs/byobu.md` - Byobu/tmux documentation (moved from config/)

### 2. Configuration Differences
- Various config file reorganizations and movements
- Some configs have been restructured differently in old-merge

## Low Priority / Already Handled

### 1. Deleted Scripts
The i3 scripts that were deleted from master don't exist in old-merge either, so no recovery needed there.

### 2. GitHub Workflows
The GitHub Actions workflows (`.github/`) were removed in old-merge, which might have been intentional.

## Recommended Recovery Actions

1. **Recover SkogAI Documentation**: The entire `.skogai/` directory contains valuable documentation and workflow guides that should be reviewed and potentially merged back.

2. **Evaluate Aider Configuration**: The aider setup in `.skogai/aider/` might have useful configurations worth preserving.

3. **Consider Shell Configs**: If you're missing bash configurations, the `bashrc`, `bash_profile`, and `bash_logout` files might be worth recovering.

4. **PowerLevel10k Theme**: If you use or want to use P10k, the `p10k.zsh` configuration could be valuable.

## Commands to Cherry-Pick Specific Items

```bash
# To view a specific file from old-merge:
git show origin/old-merge:path/to/file

# To recover a specific file:
git checkout origin/old-merge -- path/to/file

# To selectively merge content:
git checkout -p origin/old-merge -- path/to/file
```

## Next Steps

1. Review the `.skogai/` directory contents in detail
2. Decide which documentation to recover
3. Check if any aider configurations are still relevant
4. Determine if bash configurations are needed
5. Consider creating a feature branch to test recovered items before merging to master

file.content:
name: Claude Code

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: read
      issues: read
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
          
          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read

          # Optional: Give a custom prompt to Claude. If this is not specified, Claude will perform the instructions specified in the comment that tagged it.
          # prompt: 'Update the pull request description to include a summary of changes.'

          # Optional: Add claude_args to customize behavior and configuration
          # See https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-action/blob/main/docs/usage.md
          # or https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk#command-line for available options
          # claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh pr:*)'

input.old_string:
- name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
          
          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read

          # Optional: Give a custom prompt to Claude. If this is not specified, Claude will perform the instructions specified in the comment that tagged it.
          # prompt: 'Update the pull request description to include a summary of changes.'

          # Optional: Add claude_args to customize behavior and configuration
          # See https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-action/blob/main/docs/usage.md
          # or https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk#command-line for available options
          # claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh pr:*)'
input.new_string:
- name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}

          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read
            contents: write
            pull-requests: write
            issues: write

          # Custom prompt for different event types
          prompt: |
            You are helping with the dotfiles repository. When mentioned in an issue or comment:

            1. If the issue is about reviewing files: Analyze the mentioned files and provide feedback
            2. If the issue asks for specific changes: Make the requested changes and explain what you did
            3. If the issue is a question: Provide a helpful answer
            4. For PR reviews: Review the code changes and provide constructive feedback

            Always be concise and actionable in your responses.

          # Add claude_args to enable more tools and capabilities
          claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh:*),Grep,Glob,Read,Edit,Write,MultiEdit'

name: Claude Code

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: read
      issues: read
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
          
          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read

          # Optional: Give a custom prompt to Claude. If this is not specified, Claude will perform the instructions specified in the comment that tagged it.
          # prompt: 'Update the pull request description to include a summary of changes.'

          # Optional: Add claude_args to customize behavior and configuration
          # See https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-action/blob/main/docs/usage.md
          # or https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk#command-line for available options
          # claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh pr:*)'

content.text:
Updated the Claude workflow to be more actionable. The changes include:

1. **Added write permissions** - Now Claude can create/edit files, update issues, and modify PRs
2. **Custom prompt** - Provides clear instructions for different scenarios (file reviews, changes, questions, PR reviews)
3. **Enabled more tools** - Added access to file manipulation tools (Read, Edit, Write, etc.) and GitHub CLI commands
4. **Model specified** - Using the Claude Opus 4.1 model explicitly

Now when you mention @claude in an issue, it will actually be able to perform tasks like reviewing files, making changes, and providing actionable feedback instead of just commenting.

name: Claude Code

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: read
      issues: read
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}

          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read
            contents: write
            pull-requests: write
            issues: write

          # Custom prompt for different event types
          prompt: |
            You are helping with the dotfiles repository. When mentioned in an issue or comment:

            1. If the issue is about reviewing files: Analyze the mentioned files and provide feedback
            2. If the issue asks for specific changes: Make the requested changes and explain what you did
            3. If the issue is a question: Provide a helpful answer
            4. For PR reviews: Review the code changes and provide constructive feedback

            Always be concise and actionable in your responses.

          # Add claude_args to enable more tools and capabilities
          claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh:*),Grep,Glob,Read,Edit,Write,MultiEdit'

lines: -          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
+          # Grant full permissions for Claude to work with the repository
-          # Custom prompt for different event types
-            You are helping with the dotfiles repository. When mentioned in an issue or comment:
+          # Enable all tools for full functionality
-            1. If the issue is about reviewing files: Analyze the mentioned files and provide feedback
-            2. If the issue asks for specific changes: Make the requested changes and explain what you did
-            3. If the issue is a question: Provide a helpful answer
-            4. For PR reviews: Review the code changes and provide constructive feedback
-            Always be concise and actionable in your responses.
-          # Add claude_args to enable more tools and capabilities

content.text:
Updated the workflow to be simpler and more permissive:
- Full read/write permissions for content, PRs, and issues
- All tools enabled (`--allowed-tools *`)
- Removed repo-specific instructions - Claude will follow the instructions from the issue/comment instead

You're right - looking at the error message again, the workflow is already running but failing because the `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN` secret isn't set in the repository. 

To fix this, you need to:

1. Go to https://github.com/SkogAI/skogix-dotfiles-merge/settings/secrets/actions
2. Add a new secret named `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN`
3. Get the token value from https://console.anthropic.com/settings/keys (or wherever you generate Claude API tokens)

The workflow itself is fine - it's just missing the authentication token to actually use the Claude API.

file.content:
name: Claude Code

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
      pull-requests: write
      issues: write
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}

          # Grant full permissions for Claude to work with the repository
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read
            contents: write
            pull-requests: write
            issues: write

          # Enable all tools for full functionality
          claude_args: '--allowed-tools *'

content.text: Looking at the workflow again - the issue is that the `additional_permissions` section is redundant. The permissions are already defined at the job level (lines 21-26), and the `additional_permissions` field in the action itself might be causing confusion.

name: Claude Code

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
      pull-requests: write
      issues: write
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}

          # Grant full permissions for Claude to work with the repository
          additional_permissions: |
            actions: read
            contents: write
            pull-requests: write
            issues: write

          # Enable all tools for full functionality
          claude_args: '--allowed-tools *'

# Enable all tools for full functionality

on:
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request_review_comment:
    types: [created]
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  pull_request_review:
    types: [submitted]

jobs:
  claude:
    if: |
      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
      pull-requests: write
      issues: write
      id-token: write
      actions: read # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 1

      - name: Run Claude Code
        id: claude
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
